description: From French escache, from Italian scaccia.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A kind of bit for the bridle of a horse.
examples: 1684,  Thomas de Grey,  The Compleat Horse-Man, and Expert Ferrierâ€Ž[1], Fifth edition, page 236:and thus, having brought your horse to a Post set up for that purpose, and one to assist you with a Rein fastened to the rings of a half Cannon Bit or a Scatch, you having mounted his back, let your assistant hold him to the post with his head facing it,
